 1. URBAN ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT' A. URBAN ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS 1.1 Over the past 20 years, China has developed an environmental protection system employing a broad set of control instruments administered through environmental protection bureaus at all levels of government. A national environmental action plan has been developed to coordinate domestic environmental improvement efforts. China has also been a responsive partner in international efforts to control pollution and was one of the first countries to finish their Agenda 21 program following the Rio conference. 1.2 China has, despite this proactive approach, had mixed success in implementing their environmental policy. Some aspects of the record are quite good-airborne total suspended particulate (TSP) concentrations have been markedly reduced in cities in both north and south China (see Figure 1.1) and state-owned enterprise discharges of toxic metals in wastewater have fallen substantially. However, even with reductions in TSP, ambient concentrations remain above international and Chinese guidelines in many cities and sulfur dioxide (SO2) emissions have not been effectively constrained (see Figure 1.1). In line with rapidly increasing urbanization and economic growth, the demands made on water resources are exceeding supply. Water pollution continues to grow; polluted urban aquifers have increased from 20 percent in 1983 to 45 percent today. In the most recently published water quality survey, sections of rivers in 54 of 58 reporting cities failed to meet even the lowest acceptable standard, leaving few economic uses-except as waste sinks. 1.3 The social cost of this pollution is high. Over 400 million Chinese live in cities, a number expected to increase to some 800 million by 2010; annual premature deaths in urban China due to TSP are currently estimated at over 150,000. Other epidemiological work has shown a strong relationship between outdoor SO2 concentrations and mortality in northern Chinese cities. The health costs of water pollution are more difficult to measure. Raw water pollution has forced cities to move to increasingly distant and more expensive raw water sources; farmers have had to switch from irrigation with surface water to pumping groundwater, and fisheries have been damaged. For a detailed discussion please see "China: Environmental Strategy Paper" (Report No. 9669-CHA, April 1992); and "China: Urban Environmental Service Management" (Report No. 13073-CHA, December 1994).

A coal-based fuel system firing a large stock of inefficient boilers and power plants contributes to air quality problems, as does widespread dependence on coal stoves for household cooking and heating. With urban growth and rising personal incomes have come rapid increases in the volume of municipal wastewater flows-they grew from 7 billion cubic meters (ni3) annually in 1984 to 13 billion m3 in 1992. Those came with the growth of in-house water connections and of washing machines and flush toilets. Industrial wastewater discharges in urban areas declined over that same period, as reuse and other water-saving techniques increased water use efficiency. Solid waste generation has grown rapidly, and only some 25 percent of the municipal solid waste and nightsoil are disposed of to national standards. The remainder is dumped at uncovered dumping sites without leachate or gas control facilities.
 - 3 - 1.5 The nature of the discharges affecting the urban environment dictate a mix of regulatory and investment responses by different levels of government. These have been discussed in two Bank studies, the first analyzing overall environmental circumstances and policy (China: Environmental Strategy Paper, Report No. 9669-CHA, April 1992) and the second that is specific to the urban sector (China: Urban Environmental Service Management, Report No, 13073-CHA, December 1994). As described in those reports, municipal governments must seek an efficient mix of point source control through regulation and collective treatment of wastes. B. REGULATION OF POINT SOURCE POLLUTION 1.6 The regulation of point source pollution falls to the National Environmental Protection Agency (NEPA), as the secretariat of the State Council Environmental Protection Committee. NEPA drafts national regulations and other aspects of enviromnental policy for consideration by the State Council and National People's Congress. NEPA has the power to interpret national environmental regulations and standards, including those governing the operations of the local environmental protection bureaus (EPB) that work at provincial and municipal level. However, NEPA lacks implementation authority, a power left to local governments and the EPBs under them. 1.7 Provincial governments are authorized to set local environmental standards in the absence of preemptive national standards, or to impose more stringent standards than those required by the national government. Provincial EPBs coordinate these policies and, in contrast to NEPA, may play a direct role in implementation. However, the municipal, urban district and county EPBs bear the main burden of enforcement for both national and provincial regulations. The budgets, personnel appointments, and work plans of each level EPB derive from the government of that level. To aid quality control, performance must be reported to the next higher administrative level EPB, which also sets testing protocols and other performance criteria. 1.8 China's regulatory approach has focused on three instruments: environmental assessment before approval of new projects; the "three simultaneous" licensing strategy that requires integration of pollution control in project design, inclusion of the abatement measures in the actual investment, and proper operation of the abatement equipment; and a pollution levy fee chargeable against waste streams that have concentrations of pollutants above permitted levels. More recently, governments have been authorized to levy a small charge on wastewater discharges within standards. 1.9 The pollution levy fees are used mainly to finance pollution abatement in eligible enterprises. The handling of the earmarked funds has shifted over time from being granted directly back to the enterprise paying the fee to lending the funds on concessional terms for eligible pollution control investments. 1.10 NEPA now recognizes two problems with the pollution levy fee system. First, fees are typically set considerably below the marginal cost of effluent treatment, which encourages enterprises to pay the fee rather than operate or invest in treatment facilities or cleaner production technologies. Second, setting fees on the basis of concentration-based
 -4 - standards may lead to dilution as a means of compliance or reducing fee rates, and surface waters receiving discharges could fail to meet standards even though all enterprises in a watershed individually meet standards. Conversely, if assimilative capacity is high and enterprises few, the concentration standard could force compliance costs far above the damage done by the discharge. 1.11 Two more regulatory issues originate in structural features of the economy. The first arises from the fact that local governments usually own the major enterprises within their boundaries, leading to pressures to relax regulation or fee collection in the interest of employment and profits. The second is that the enterprises operating on the periphery of cities may have a large impact on municipal environmental quality, yet fall outside municipal control. This latter problem is particularly acute with the small-scale township and village industrial enterprises (TVIEs). Individual TVIEs' enforcement costs are high relative to output, yet in the aggregate, TVIE pollution has a large impact on the downstream environment. 1.12 NEPA has a large research and experimentation program under way to identify new approaches to overcome these and other regulatory problems. Among these initiatives is the use of catchment-specific mass-based pollution permits to replace the concentration-based standards and fees. More generally, NEPA seeks effective market- based pollution control mechanisms to complement the national shift to a market-based economy and to avoid many of the problems of enterprise-specific regulation. The Bank supports NEPA's program through the Environmental Technical Assistance Project (Credit 2522-CHA) and investment projects such as the one now proposed. C. COLLECTIVE WASTE HANDLING AND TREATMENT 1.13 Urban environmental services, which include wastewater collection and treatment systems and solid waste collection and treatment, fall under the purview of the Construction Commissions found in every Chinese city. Overall regulatory guidance and standard setting is provided by the Ministry of Construction and the provincial Construction Bureaus. The Ministry and Bureaus set national and provincial policy for urban and regional planning, infrastructure development planning, and facility operating standards. They also specify financial accounting procedures and goals. Based on those policies and standards, the municipal commissions provide or regulate providers of the actual service. The municipal commissions are typically among the largest and most powerful of the municipal administrative bodies, having under them bureaus or companies directly providing key urban services. 1.14 Chinese cities are characterized by a good correspondence between expenditure responsibility and control over revenue. This sets them apart from cities in many developing countries, which have been characterized by inadequate funding to meet mandated services. Chinese cities also tend to have well-staffed administrations, with their broad control over the local economy making them an attractive employer. These advantages have helped China achieve piped water supply to nearly 90 percent of all urban residents, but has not automatically led to high levels of service in every field. The
 - 5 - low level of adequate solid waste disposal was cited earlier and local watercourses continue to serve as both drains and sewers for nearly 40 percent of the area of Chinese cities. Wastewater treatment levels are low, with only 4.5 percent of municipal flows treated in 1992. Cities have given priority to water supply, roads, and enterprise investment over environmental services. Yet rapidly growing problems with raw water quality are forcing recognition across cities that wastes need to be adequately handled. 1.15 The major policy problem identified in China: Urban Environmental Service Management was the failure to charge, or charge adequately, for environmental services. Although cities have long charged for water delivery, residential wastewater charges are virtually unknown, while charges to enterprises have been rare, and where collected, fall far below operating needs. Solid waste collection fees are charged more often, but those services still require substantial subsidies. An important consequence of this failure to charge adequate user fees is that service investment programs have failed to meet goals due to lack of finance. The Ministry of Construction estimates that two thirds of the municipal wastewater treatment plants either do not operate, or operate far below capacity due to lack of funds. Moreover, when users do not have to pay, they have no incentive to reduce waste volumes. This creates the need for larger service systems when they are provided. D. BANK GROUP SECTOR STRATEGY 1.16 The Bank Group highlighted enhancing environmental protection and reducing infrastructure bottlenecks as two of the five areas of concentration under the China Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) discussed by the Board on March 18, 1997. Our close collaboration with the Chinese government covers both the regulatory and service provision aspects of urban environmental management. The China: Environmental Strategy Paper sector study led to the Environmental Technical Assistance Project noted earlier, which assists NEPA in its efforts to find more efficient regulatory methods, improve staff capabilities, and bolster environmental monitoring. That project complements Bank-administered, Japanese Government-fmanced technical assistance to NEPA covering (a) the environmental impact assessment process; (b) waste minimization and pollution control in rural industries; (c) hazardous/toxic waste management; (d) economic/financial mechanisms for environmental management; and (e) environmental information management systems. The Global Environmental Facility has supported studies and projects on the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, the loss of biodiversity in China, and ozone-depleting substances. 1.17 We are currently supporting six urban environmental projects in 12 cities, which incorporate policy, financing and organizational strategies for improved environmental regulation and service delivery at the provincial and municipal levels, in addition to national regulatory assistance. Another five ongoing investment projects in another 12 cities include related issues such as municipal water supply and sanitation. The initial portfolio of projects focused on China's largest cities-Shanghai, Beijing and Tianjin- and those located primarily in the wealthier northeast and coastal provinces. Enviromnental pressures remain high in those areas and cooperation would continue, as
 -6- with the Second Shanghai Sewerage Project (Loan 3987-CHA) and the proposed project. However, the Hubei Urban Environmental Project (Loan 3966/Credit 2799-CHA) and the recently approved Yunnan Environment Project (Loan 4055/Credit 2892-CHA) mark a shift in geographic focus, moving toward inland and poorer areas. Hubei, a medium- income province, is located in central China, while operations in poor areas, like Yunnan, and others being prepared in Guangxi, Hebei and Sichuan Provinces and in Chongqing Municipality, would further test the sustainability of policy and institutional interventions. 1.18 A review of ongoing Bank Group projects in the sector in China and elsewhere presents relevant lessons in the provision and management of urban environmental services and in industrial pollution control. 1.19 Bankwide municipal management sector work (Urban Sector Delivery: Finding the Right Incentives) emphasizes the need to assign functional responsibilities appropriately and link revenue to expenditures. In China's case, environmental services are fittingly provided at the municipal level, where a high percentage of government revenue is also captured. China: Urban Environmental Service Management concludes that the major failing in environmental services has been dependence on municipal budget transfers to fund services, while greater reliance on user charges would be affordable, induce resource conservation, and create a more dependable income stream. Similarly, the Operation and Evaluation Department's review of Bank-financed water and sanitation projects (Water Supply and Sanitation Projects: The Bank Experience 1967- 1989) found generally good physical performance but less successful financial viability and overall sectoral development. For that reason, ensuring adequate levels of tariff was a focus of the policy dialogue during project preparation, with the result that water supply, wastewater and district heating tariffs were adjusted prior to project preappraisal and appraisal. This openness to introducing improvements was seen during preparation of the Urban Environmental Service Study, for which cities in Hubei and Yunnan were used as case studies. 1.20 The Bank's experience in industrial pollution control includes projects in China, as well as in Mexico, Brazil, India, Indonesia and the Russian Federation. A review of completed projects (Industry and Environment: Pattern in World Bank Lending) emphasizes the need for political commitment, clear standards and regulations, incentives to comply, and institutional capability to monitor and enforce standards. When industrial pollution abatement subloans are involved, the following conditions increase likelihood of success: a profitable and growing industrial sector, flexibility in choice of technology, availability of funds at close-to-market terms, and targeting on sources that can yield significant improvement in the ambient environment. 1.21 The environmental pollution control component of the proposed project draws on these lessons and those in the two recent environmental sector studies. The latter stress issues of political commitment, appropriate standards and incentives, and institutional monitoring and enforcement capabilities. This project addresses those issues by improving the monitoring and enforcement capacities of Shandong's provincial and
 -7 - municipal EPBs by aiming to provide training, institutional development and equipment. Competent enforcement of regulations would be enhanced by requiring the Shandong Environmental Protection Bureau (SEPB) to enhance the collection of pollution levies in Shandong. 1.22 Consequently, the proposed project responds to Bank Group experience and CAS objectives for the environment and infrastructure development. Environmental amelioration would be enhanced by an improved regulatory environment, protection of critical water and land resources, and reduction of current pollution loads. Infrastructure expansion would benefit from investment in wastewater and solid waste collection and treatment as well as in water supply expansion, commercialization of operating agencies, an improved tariff policy to fund maintenance of the existing systems as well as their future expansion, and modem operating techniques. The Bank Group's strategy flows from and supports China's Environmental Action Plan and Agenda 21 initiatives, which provide the basis for joint Government and Bank action in the environmental sector, especially in regard to the urban environment. The provincial focus recognizes the effective decentralization of regulatory and investment authority in China, and draws on local political power and commitment to induce wider use of the solutions to be demonstrated under the project.
 -8 - 2. THE PROJECT AREA A. ECONOMIC SETTING 2.1 Shandong is a coastal province in eastern China with a land area of 156,700 km2, including a large peninsula. It has a 3,000 km coastline on the Bohai and Yellow Seas and shares borders with Hebei, Henan, Anhui, and Jiangsu provinces. There are eight main lakes and nine rivers within the province. The major river is the Huang He (Yellow River), which in the western part of the province forms the border with Hebei. 2.2 The 1995 population of the province was reported at 87 million, of which the urban population accounted for about 32 percent. Overall population growth was reported at 0.38 percent per year; the nonagricultural population had grown quickly in the past 20 years, from 5.6 million in 1975 to 21.7 million in 1995. In contrast, the agricultural population during the same period had remained about the same, 64.0 million in 1975 and 65.3 million in 1995. However, these data do not capture the large influx of migrants who have not gained official urban status, nor do they reflect the dynamic growth of small towns. With Shandong's rapid industrial and service sector growth, urbanization is expected to continue at a high rate through the next decade and beyond. 2.3 The economy of the province has grown rapidly over the past decade. In 1995, the gross domestic product (GDP) was Y 500 billion, with an average annual growth rate of about 16.7 percent from 1990 to 1995. Of the total GDP, Y 101 billion was generated by the primary sector, Y 237 billion by the secondary and Y 162 billion from the tertiary sector. The proportion of GDP generated by the primary, secondary and tertiary sectors has changed substantially, from 35:43:22 in 1985 to 20:48:32 in 1995. This indicates that, although all three sectors showed robust growth during the last 10 years, growth was most rapid in the tertiary sector and slowest in agriculture. 2.4 The rapid growth of the industrial and service sectors has resulted in serious environmental problems in urban areas, particularly in Jinan, the capital city, and in the coastal cities of Qingdao, Weihai and Yantai, and in Zibo. Because of Shandong's (and China's) vast coal deposits and paucity of natural gas and oil, almost all thermal power generation, industrial process heat, and residential heating utilize coal as the major energy source. Were the coal burned efficiently and economically in large boilers equipped with pollution control equipment (with which efficiency reaches acceptable levels above 85 percent), air pollution would not be as severe as it is. Shandong, however, has the largest mass emissions of SO2 of all the provinces of China; air quality in all major cities is poor, particularly during the heating season; and the provincial capital, Jinan, ranked twenty- second in 1995 in the NEPA list of 37 "most environmentally stressed cities in China." Some rivers have become merely wastewater canals since the late 1980s. For example,
 -9- water in the Xiaoqing River fails to meet the least stringent Class V national ambient water quality standards over its entire length. The pollution in the Xiaoqing River Basin (XRB) has posed serious threats to human health, as well as to economic development. Contaminants in groundwater have made drinking water unsafe, requiring the province to finance the construction of 237 deep wells and 11 water storage reservoirs near the river. 2.5 Investment in industrial pollution control in Shandong amounted to Y 2.1 billion in 1995, ranking the province in second place (after Liaoning) among the 27 provinces in China. More than 50 percent of the investments were in wastewater treatment and pollution control. B. THE PROJECT AREAS 2.6 The cities and their rural hinterlands selected to benefit from the proposed investments exemplify the development successes and environmental problems in Shandong (see AnnexJ1); their location is shown on Map IBRD 28428. Jinan 2.7 Jinan Municipality comprises an area of 8,227 km2 and has a population of 5.4 million. It consists of five urban districts, four counties, and one county-level city. Jinan City has an area of 2,119 km2 and a population of 2.5 million. The core area of the city is 110 km2, with a population of 1.5 million. The Xiaoqing River rises in Jinan, fed by springs and from infiltration from the nearby Yellow River; it is a prime water source for Jinan Municipality, ultimately flowing into Laizhou Bay, some 237 km east of the city. The river has nine tributaries and outfalls in the Jinan area, and six catchment systems in all. It passes through 18 cities and counties, including Jinan, Zibo, Binzhou Prefecture, Dongying and Weifang. Up to the 1960s, the river's waters were clean; however, the rapid industrial development has led to severe contamination. 2.8 Water Supply System. The Jinan Water Supply Company (JWSC) was established in 1936 to provide a supply of about 7,600 m3/day at that time, through 40 km of pipe network for about 1,700 residential and industrial units in the commercial area of the city. The system has been progressively extended, with the present installed design capacity reported around 895,000 m3/day, although the actual available supply is restricted to some 714,000 m3/day due to resource constraints. The existing water distribution network now covers an area of some 364 km2 and extends to about 1,150 km. 2.9 Groundwater has traditionally been the main water resource for the city. However, this resource has been progressively supplemented in recent years by supplies from impounding reservoirs and direct abstractions from the Yellow River in order to control the "mining" of groundwater caused by overabstraction of this resource. 2.10 Water Demand. The water demand projections through the planning horizon of 2010 have been estimated based on the following broad assumptions: population served; industrial output value; and other uses (including public facilities, fire fighting and
 -10- system losses). Other water uses are expected to reduce from 18 percent (actual in 1995) to 16 percent in 2000 and 15 percent by 2010, reflecting improved system operational efficiency and reduced system losses. The water demand and resource projections indicate a supply deficit of 0.25 million m3/day in 1995, increasing to about 0.86 million m3/day in the year 2000, based on per capita demands varying in the range of 190 to 300 liters per capita per day (l/c/d) over the planning period to 2010 (details in Annex 2). 2.11 Water Resource Planning. In order to address the apparent deficit in supply, JWSC has identified the main system deficiencies and has developed a long-term resource strategy. The deficiencies and problems include: insufficient surface water; "mining" of groundwater; low reliability of Yellow River source without storage; equipment defects at Huanghe No. 1 Water Treatment Plant (WTP); low system pressures in certain areas; old pipe networks; and water wastage. The development plan is based on least-cost resource analysis. 2.12 Under this project, the Queshan Reservoir Yellow River abstraction scheme would be implemented. This would provide a continuous supply of 440,000 m3/day of desilted raw water to fully utilize the existing treatment capacity at the Huanghe No. 2 WTP, thus providing a supply of 400,000 m3/day of fully treated water to the city. Assurances were obtained during negotiations that JWSC would, not later than December 31, 2000, strengthen its distribution systems to handle an increased supply of about 400,000 m3/day offiully treated water to Jinan. 2.13 Wastewater System. The total amount of wastewater discharged in Jinan was 204.6 million tons in 1995, of which 117.2 million tons were from industrial sources. Only 53 percent of industrial wastewater met the effluent standards for all pollutants. Common problems of unreliable technology and poor operation of the end-of-pipe treatment facilities is one of the important reasons for the low compliance rate with effluent standards, the majority of wastewater flows in open channels untreated to the surface and groundwater systems, causing extensive long-term environmental damage and posing immediate-term health hazards. A Sewerage Master plan was originally prepared in 1983; this was updated in 1993 and provides the basis for the sewerage planning for the city. The urban area of Jinan is divided into seven catchments comprising Jiqi, Jiluo, Daming Lake, Liuhangtou, Huangtai Qili River, Wangsheren and Danjia catchments totaling about 140 km2 in area. 2.14 The existing sewer system comprises about 145 km of pipes in the catchments of Jiluo, Daming, Liuhangtou and Huangtai, in sizes between 300 and 1,500 mm diameter, mostly of concrete pipe construction, with small lengths of brick culverts and pipes. There are a number of pump stations, the most significant of which is the Juluo Bridge station, built in 1985, of 230,000 m3/day capacity, to lift sewage to the Jilan Sewage Treatment Works (STW), which has a capacity of 220,000 m3/day; a second STW would be required in due course as flows increase to reflect improved interception and connection rates, and economic growth. The STW, which was financed in part with bilateral aid, and completed in 1995, is presently underutilized pending the construction
 - 11 - of new interceptor sewers to convey flows to the STW. An understanding was obtained during negotiations that Shandong Province (SP) would cause the Jinan Municipal Drainage Company (JMDC) to commission and continuously operate the STW in a manner satisfactory to the Bank, on completion of the water management component of the project. 2.15 The present wastewater flow from all seven catchments in the city is about 680,000 m3/day, comprising about 30 percent domestic and 70 percent industrial flows. The existing sewerage system is partly combined and partly separate, and is seriously inadequate, with large parts of the 145 km of main and secondary sewers not functioning satisfactorily due to siltation and blocking of the inverted siphons at river crossings. All wastewater flows discharge directly or indirectly into watercourses within the city or to the Xiaoqing River through existing sewers. As a result, the water quality in watercourses and lakes within the city and the Xiaoqing River has deteriorated to below National Surface Water Class V Standard. 2.16 The Jinan STW is designed to provide full secondary treatment and sludge disposal facilities, to deal with wastewater flows from the catchments of Jiluo, Daming Lake, Liuhangtou and Huangtai, totaling 0.44 million m3/day in 1995. The projected wastewater flows from the above four catchments are estimated at about 0.58 million m3! day by 2010. 2.17 Major system requirements are for investrnents to fully utilize the existing capacity of the Jinan STW; improve the watercourses and natural environment in the city; protect groundwater resources from pollution; reduce pollution of the Daming Lake; and improve water quality of the Xiaoqing River. The second phase of this STW would be built during 2001-15; meanwhile, excess flows would continue to spill over into the Xiaoqing River (further details are shown in Annex 2). THE PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT'S ENVIRONMENTAL STRATEGY 2.23 Recognizing the problems described above, the Shandong Provincial Government (SPG) issued three legal documents in mid-1990s to reverse the deterioration of the province's environmental quality and initiated various actions aimed at achieving this goal. They are: (a) A Decision on Strengthening Water Pollution Prevention and Control (No. 31, 1996); (b) A Notice on the Establishment of a Special Fund for Controlling Pollution Generated From Pulp and Paper Enterprises, Breweries, and Distilleries, issued on March 7, 1996; and (c) Measures for Collecting the Urban Wastewater Treatment Fee
 - 13 - in Shandong Province. SPG is also implementing existing national environmental programs. 2.24 The first document-A Decision on Strengthening Water Pollution Prevention and Control (No. 31, 1996)-sets a timetable for wastewater discharge control. It stipulates that by the end of 1997, wastewater discharged from key industrial pollution sources located in the XRB should meet the national effluent standards. By the end of the year 2000, all industrial pollution sources in Shandong Province should meet national effluent standards. 2.25 The second document-A Notice on the Establishment of a Special Fund for Controlling Pollution Generated From Pulp and Paper Enterprises, Breweries, and Distilleries-was issued on March 7, 1996, to accelerate the control of water pollution generated from these most polluting industries. The document requires enterprises producing pulp and paper and alcoholic beverages to contribute to a special fund as long as the concentration of pollutants in their wastewater exceeds the national standards. The contribution of enterprises to the fund is based on annual production output: Y 100 per ton of pulp: Y 50 per ton of alcohol, and Y 20 per ton of beer. 2.26 The third document-Measures for Collecting the Urban Wastewater Treatment Fee in Shandong Province-is designed to ease the problem of capital shortages for construction and to cover the maintenance and operating cost of centralized wastewater treatment plants. The provincial government issued Provisional measures, mandating the collection of urban wastewater treatment fees from working units and individuals located within the service area of centralized treatment plants. The rate of fee would not exceed 30 percent of the current price of tap water. 2.27 To stop the continual decline in air quality and to achieve the goal of meeting Class II ambient air quality standards in main cities in Shandong by the year 2000, SPG considers the control of air pollution caused by coal combustion as the main task in the next 15 years. The six main target cities include Jinan, Qingdao, Zibo, Taian, Weihai and Yantai. The province plans to increase both the existing area of gas supply and the existing area of district heating by 10 percent by 2000, and by 30 percent by 2010. The province also plans to raise the coverage ratio of soot control area to 85 percent by 2000 and to 100 percent by 2010. In addition, controlling air pollution caused by the quick increase in the number of automobiles in urban areas is considered another task in the next decade. 2.28 In response to the serious pollution problems in the XRB, the Shandong People's Congress issued the Shandong Xiaoqing River Basin Water Pollution Prevention and Control Regulation (the Regulation) in 1995. There are several articles in the Regulation that are not covered by existing national laws, regulations, or programs. The Regulation is more advanced in several aspects than the existing national environmental programs. It reflects the three changes in the approach to industrial pollution prevention and control addressed by the Second National Conference on Control and Prevention Of Industrial
 - 14- Pollution in 1993: first, employ cleaner production instead of end-of-pipe treatment; second, move from concentration-based discharge standards to a dual system (combining concentration-based and mass-based discharge standard); and third, switch from sole reliance on on-site treatment facilities at industrial enterprises to a combination of centralized treatment facilities and on-site treatment facilities. 2.29 A Xiaoqing River Comprehensive Pollution Prevention and Control Plan of 1994 (the Plan) was approved by the Shandong People's Congress in 1995. The Plan initiates six main actions for controlling Xiaoqing River pollution: First, the province prepared and began to control 100 serious industrial polluting sources by 1997 (Y 70 million has already been invested). The total investment in point-source control (including the control of the 100 serious industrial pollution sources) is about Y 859 million. Second, to built 11 centralized wastewater treatment plants (with a total capacity of 725,000 tons/ day) in the river basin by 2000. The estimated total investment is some Y 1.4 billion. Two municipal treatment plants have already been built-one in Jinan, the other in Zibo. Third, the province plans to invest Y 7.8 million to control nonpoint-source pollution in the XRB. Fourth, the province is preparing to undertake major river training works (including dredging silt) on the Xiaoqing River, with a investment estimated at Y 2.5 billion. Fifth, the province would continuously invest in solving drinking water problems caused by groundwater pollution. Sixth, a Yellow River Water Diversion Project is planned by the province to divert water from the Yellow River to the Xiaoqing River to sustain higher levels of flow and thereby reduce the concentration of pollutants in that river by simple dilution. A survey of the principal point sources of pollution in the XRB has shown that some 90 percent is produced by the top 44 polluters-of these, the top three account for an estimated 50 percent of total chemical oxygen demand (COD) and toxic discharges. Time-bound Environmental Action Plans have been prepared by Shandong to address these problems. D. FORMULATION OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT 2.30 Environmental Policy in Shandong. The provincial government considers that the environmental degradation in Shandong is "serious," due mainly to rapid industrial growth as result of the transition to a market economy, aggravated by historic mistakes, the use of "backward technology" and a shortage of funds. To combat further environmental deterioration, the province and the three cities that would be included in this project have identified environmental policies and programs that are aimed at substantially reducing their main pollution problems by the year 2000. These efforts would permit economic growth while aiming to markedly reduce industrial pollution, improve municipal environmental treatment measures and provide ecological protection. Particular mention is made in these plans to regional watershed protection as well as environmental management. Main emphasis would be given to three areas that are most environmentally stressed: the area around Lake Weishan in the south, the industrial heartland area of the XRB in the central part of the province and northeastern peninsula area on the coast. XRB has been identified by the State Council of the national government as one of the most polluted minor river basins in China, and selected as a
 - 15 - priority candidate for managed cleanup. The XRB and the peninsula are the two areas of geographical focus of this project. 2.31 Bank Group Assistance Strategy and Rationale for Bank Group Involvement in the Project. The China Country Assistance Strategy highlights enhancing environmental protection and reducing infrastructure bottlenecks as two of the five areas of strategic focus. This project specifically responds to these two foci, improving highly polluted and deteriorating water resources and providing for their subsequent protection, facilitating more stringent environmental regulation, and reducing current pollution loads. It would also provide urban environmental infrastructure for wastewater, water supply and industrial waste reduction, backed up by a strengthened urban services tariff policy aiming to sustain infrastructure investments and improve asset management and operations. 2.32 The project follows from previous Bank Group-assisted urban environmental management projects and furthers a recently adopted strategy initiated with a similar project in Hubei of moving from the wealthier provinces to less wealthy areas. With these projects, the Bank Group is facilitating broader national debate on strategies for urban environmental improvement focusing on sustainable financing mechanisms, rational and workable local-level institutional utility management arrangements and least- cost long-life public utility investment programs to meet urban development service needs in an affordable manner. The project would, in addition, build on our institutional relationships with groups such as NEPA, the Ministry of Construction, and the Chinese Mayors Association. 2.33 Lessons Learned from Previous Bank Group Assistance. Important lessons have been learned in three areas of concern to the present project: provision and management of urban environmental services; pollution control; and project preparation and implementation. With respect to the provision and management of urban environmental services, Bank municipal management sector work ("Urban Service Delivery; Finding the Right Incentives") emphasizes the need to properly assign functional responsibilities and line revenue to expenditures. In China's case, environmental services are appropriately provided at the municipal level, where a high percentage of government revenue is also captured. Recent sector work ("China: Urban Environmental Service Management," Report 13073-CHA) concludes that the major failing in environmental services has been dependence on municipal budget transfer to fund services, while greater reliance on user charges would be affordable, induce resource conservation, and create a more dependable income stream. For that reason, increasing tariffs has been a major focal point of the policy dialogue in this project. This responds, too, to a major finding in the Operations Evaluation Department (OED) review of Bank water and sanitation projects ("Water Supply and Sanitation Projects; The Bank Experience 1967-1989"), wherein physical performance was generally good, but sustaining financial viability and overall sectoral development was less successful. 2.34 In matters of pollution control, the Bank's experience draws on recent projects in China, as well as in Mexico, Brazil, India, Indonesia and the Russian Federation. A
 - 16- review of Bank experience ("Industry and Environment: Patterns in World Bank Lending") emphasizes the need for political commitment, clear standards and regulations, incentives to comply, and institutional capability to monitor and enforce standards. When industrial pollution abatement subloans are involved, the following conditions increase likelihood of success: a profitable and growing industrial sector, flexibility in choice of technology, availability of funds at close-to-market terms, and targeting sources that can yield significant improvement in the ambient environment. The pollution abatement components draw on these lessons and those in two recent sector studies, as well as the recently completed four short-term environmental priority studies undertaken during the preparation of this project. The latter stress issues of political commitment, appropriate standards and incentives, and institutional monitoring and enforcement capabilities. This project addresses those issues through action plans seeking to maximize project impact beyond the direct benefits of the investments, while strengthening the provincial and municipal EPBs. 2.35 With respect to project preparation and implementation, Shandong Province is one of the more experienced recipients of Bank assistance. Over the past 15 years, the province has participated in 27 Bank-assisted projects, with the highest-rated project performance record. It should, therefore, serve as a good test for the Bank's initiative to place more responsibility on member governments for project preparation and shorten the time of project preparation. However, the responsibility for preparing this project has been with sector agencies with no experience of Bank approaches to project formulation; this delayed preparation. The inexperience precipitated the use of supplementary consultant funds to enhance quality at entry; and necessitated inclusion in the project of institutional strengthening, project management and training components, which initially Shandong considered nonessential.

LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT 3.25 The project has four components that entail land acquisition and resettlement: (a) the Jinan Yellow River Water Supply Project; (b) the Jinan Waste Water Collection Project; (c) the Yantai Municipal District Heating Project; and (d) the Weihai Municipal District Heating Project. In compliance with Operational Directive 4.30, each subcomponent has prepared a RAP, all of which have been reviewed by the Mission's resettlement expert and found to be generally in accordance with the requirements of the Bank. Each RAP sets out: (a) land acquisition and resettlement policies and principles; (b) baseline surveys; (c) description of resettlement sites; (d) resettlement implementation arrangements; (e) implementation schedule; (f) rehabilitation of livelihoods; (g) costs and budget; (h) participation of project-affected people (PAP); (i) grievance mechanisms: and (j) monitoring and evaluation of RAP implementation. 3.27 Rural Resettlement (Jinan Yellow River Water Supply Project). For the 304 households that require physical relocation, two-thirds would be provided new residential sites nearby while the remainder (all from one village) would be relocated collectively to

 - 37 - 5. FINANCE A. FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT 5.1 Since 1978, Chinese economic reforms have evolved gradually toward an increasingly decentralized financial system in China. Most industrial production and prices have become free of government control, and enterprises have to purchase most of their inputs at market prices. Enterprise reform has become a high priority of the Government. In this connection, the guiding principles of the recently promulgated "regulations on transforming the management mechanisms of state-owned industrial enterprises" are to separate government administration from enterprise management, increase the autonomy and accountability of state-owned enterprises, and increase competition and market orientation. The reform efforts to improve economic policies and enterprise efficiencies are essential for sustaining both economic development and environmental protection in the longer run. 5.2 In order for the enterprises to assume their increased responsibilities efficiently and effectively, the strengthening of their financial management is essential. Toward this end, the proposed project would support the applications of modern management techniques and huuman resource development for the utility companies. B. ACCOUNTING 5.3 Under the project, the following accounting systems, in accordance with regulations prescribed by the Ministry of Finance, apply. 5.4 Enterprise Accounting. All state-owned enterprises in China follow a unified enterprise accounting system. The accounting framework was developed in the context of a highly centralized planned economy. With a view to complementing the ongoing efforts to deepen reforms in the financial sector and enterprise management, the accounting system in China needed modernization to permit satisfactory financial management in an increasingly decentralized and market-oriented environment. As a first step, the general principles of enterprise (the term to include public utilities such as water, sewerage, and district heating companies) accounting were revised by the Ministry of Finance from July 1, 1993 to be more consistent with internationally generally accepted accounting practice. Further reforms are under way to combine aspects of the Constructioii Unit Accounting System with the Enterprise Accounting System for state-owned enterprises that are responsible for construction of their own investment projects. Until the Government has completed the modifications, all enterprises included in the project would follow both systems. 5.5 Government Accounting. The regular government department accounts reflect expenditures incurred against budget allocations by SP or its municipal governments.
 - 38 - Accounting is handled in a decentralized manner through transfers to subunits from which actual expenditures are made and recorded on a cash basis. Accounts are kept at all levels, and each subunit reflects in its accounts the budget allocation it receives from the unit above. 5.6 Project Accounts. Project accounts would be maintained by SPPMO, in accordance with the State Construction Unit Accounting System. This system prescribes generally accepted accounting practices, including double-entry bookkeeping, subsidiary ledger accounting, and rules for capitalizing and expending various items of expenditure. It also sets out detailed accounting definitions for capital works, cash control, receivables and payables. In addition, it identifies a number of basic monthly, quarterly and annual reporting formats, including funds flow statements and balance sheets. The construction accounting system is comprehensive, and is adequate for the proposed project. C. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION 6.1 The project is consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) priorities of environmental protection and alleviation of infrastructure bottlenecks, as described in Chapter 2, and responds to China's priorities by supporting a national pilot program to implement a river basin approach at the Xiaoqing River in Shandong Province. Specifically, the project would support: (a) the provincial and municipal environmental protection bureaus (EPBs) in their efforts to prepare and implement a comprehensive river basin program, including the prioritization of interventions based on their cost- effectiveness; (b) the establishment of financially sustainable utilities through the creation of new corporations with a separate budget, such as the Jinan Drainage Company, and through a tariff policy that assures the coverage of operational costs and debt service and an increasing contribution to future investments; (c) reduction of water pollution from Jinan city through the expansion of sewerage services and full utilization of the existing treatment capacity, thereby protecting the urban environment and the health of their people and those living downstream of these cities; (d) protection of groundwater and improvement of water supply in Jinan, through a shift toward surface water and stabilizing of water supply even during the dry season; (e) reduction of air pollution in Weihai and Yantai through more efficient central district heating systems, replacing a large number of small inefficient boilers and stoves; with the added benefits of minimizing economic costs through large coal savings; and (f) reduction of industrial pollution through a line of credit and technical assistance that focuses on the dissemination of cost-effective cleaner technologies.
 -47 - B. ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 6.2 In recent years, the cost of environmental degradation caused by urban pollution has become very apparent in Shandong Province and has translated into financial losses and the disappearance of whole sectors, such as aquaculture in the estuary of the Xiaoqing. In response, the Province plans to embark on a comprehensive program to reduce pollution. Such program represents a major investment for the Province and a challenging task of coordinating a wide array of activities and institutions. Implementation of the program therefore requires careful prioritization of interventions to maximize their net benefit in terms of environmental improvements. Since environmental benefits can only partially be translated into monetary values, often the choice of priority interventions has to be guided by cost-effectiveness considerations. Such a least-cost approach to achieve environmental improvement was successfully applied in the selection of several project components. Three of the components achieve cost-effectiveness by making better use of existing but underutilized urban infrastructure. The proposed project would provide the critical missing link to fully utilize existing capacity, e.g., the water supply component in Jinan would allow the existing water treatment plant to increase capacity utilization from less than 25 percent to about 100 percent. The environmental subloans to industry, in turn, focus on cost-effective interventions of pollution prevention and waste minimization, thereby helping industry to achieve a satisfactory environmental performance at a lower cost compared to traditional end-of-pipe solutions. The proposed district heating components in Weihai and Yantai are not only the environmentally most benign solutions, but they are also the least-cost economic alternatives before accounting for environmental benefits. 6.3 In addition to investments, Shandong Province and its cities need changes in policy and institutional structures to achieve environmental improvements. A key problem are urban environmental services that are priced too low to discourage waste generation or to generate the self-financing needed to build, maintain and operate services such as district heating or wastewater treatment. Therefore, investment choices were made in view of supporting institutional and tariff reforms, such as the creation of the Jinan Municipal Drainage Company (JMDC), which takes over responsibility for wastewater from a former government bureau. City and Sector Choices 6.4 Specific investment choices within sectors and cities responded to local priorities and long-run municipal strategies to expand urban environmental services and to meet minimum national ambient environmental quality standards. Three cities were selected: Jinan, the capital of Shandong Province, which ranks fourth among the 37 "environmentally most stressed cities in China" according to a National Environmental Protection Agency (NEPA) pollution index, was selected because of its major environmental problems and its immediate impact on the water quality of the Xiaoqing River. The other two cities, Yantai and Weihai, are medium-size cities that had a clearly defined strategy to address their air pollution problems through the expansion of district
 -48 - heating and offered opportunities to demonstrate new technologies that would be relevant to other, similarly sized cities in the province. Credit Line for Pollution Abatement 6.5 Reducing industrial pollution is a cornerstone of the XRB program. The Province has established a subloans facility, to be initially capitalized at $10 million, for which it requested a Bank loan of $5 million. In line with China's new market-oriented approach to lending for industries, the pollution prevention and control line of credit would introduce strict financial and technical evaluation criteria, and would not offer concessional interest rates. The line of credit would be a transitional and catalytic financial mechanism to help overcome the credit-market constraints for environmental investments (more fully described in the China Department's 1995 Capital Market Sector Study). The major benefit of the facility would be the demonstration of a cost-effective approach to pollution reduction by applying cleaner production, waste minimization, and waste recovery techniques. The fund focuses on top-ranked small- and medium-size major polluters that discharge into the Xiaoqing River; the pollution reduction is estimated to be significant at an enterprise level, but, given the magnitude of industrial pollution in the river basin, the expected impact on the water quality of the Xiaoqing River would onjy be marginal. Water Supply in Jinan 6.6 The purpose of the Jinan Water Supply Component is to halt groundwater depletion while meeting the increasing water demand from Jinan's urban population and industry. The project would achieve this by increasing the supply of surface water from the Yellow River and by compensating for seasonal fluctuations of the river flow. The immediate benefit to the serviced population of about 1 million is an increased water supply of 400,000 m3/day, which would effectively reduce current water shortages. The economic net benefit of improved water supply is about Y 150 million and the economic rate of return (ERR) 18 percent. The long-term benefit includes a slightly reduced groundwater extraction, which is a first step toward a return to sustainable levels of groundwater management. 6.7 The project represents the least-cost option because of its effective use of existing but underutilized infrastructure, its closeness to the existing water treatment plant and to its consumers, and the contribution to a reduced groundwater extraction. Alternative schemes were considered but were more costly or unsustainable: (a) the investment cost of a surface water extraction scheme at Tianshan on the Yellow River, upstream of Jinan to supply the same volume of water would be 58 percent higher and the unit cost per ton of treated water per day would be 11 percent higher than for the proposed project. (b) If the additional volume of water were to be supplied from groundwater, overall extraction in the year 2000 would reach about 1.2 million m3/day, more than double the long-term sustainable extraction volume of 500,000 m3/day. Overextraction would accelerate the drop in the average groundwater level, which has already dropped from about 29 meters
 - 49 - (m) to less than 26 m above sea level over the last 30 years and further reduce the flow of Jinan's famous springs. Reduced spring flow also reduces the flow of surface water within Jinan and to the Xiaoqing River and, as a consequence, increases the concentration of pollution from industrial and domestic effluents, specifically during the dry season. In the long run, overextraction could lead to a irreversible loss of the groundwater resource. 6.8 Improvement in water use efficiency is a critical element in achieving the project objectives. Industrial water demand is projected to increase from about 650,000 m3/day in 1996 to 950,000 m3/day in 2010, assuming an ambitious annual 6 percent decline of the water consumption per unit of industrial output. Jinan has a track record of already having achieved, between 1990 and 1995, a reduction from 15,000 m3/Y million to 6,000 (a 20 percent per year reduction). Nonetheless, achieving such sustained water use efficiency would require special attention to and incentives for water conservation measures in industry. For private households, rising water tariffs are likely to encourage water conservation: a price elasticity of -0.17 for domestic per capita water consumption was estimated based on the last 15 years of JWSC's sales. However, rising incomes and living standards would more than compensate this impact with an estimated per capita income elasticity of 0.22. As a result, aggregate demand from households (including public buildings) for which the population growth rate is estimated at 2.3 percent (1.9 percent after 2000) would increase from about 300,000 m3/day in 1995 to over 650,000 m3/day in 2010. Jinan Wastewater 6.9 The Jinan Wastewater Component is a first step to reduce the city's contribution to the pollution of the Xiaoqing River. The proposed project would provide the missing connection to the sewerage network and enhance its collection capacity to allow the STW to operate at its full capacity of 220,000 m3/day, or about 45 percent of the total waste stream. The project has the immediate benefit to provide improved sewerage services to a service population of about 1 million, and to reduce Jinan's pollution load into the Xiaoqing River by about 32,000 tons of chemical oxygen demand (COD) annually. While this would reduce COD concentration in the river by almost 100 mg/l (or 45 percent), river quality would still exceed Class V Standards of 25 mg/l by a factor of 5 and make it necessary for Jinan to further increase its treatment capacity after completion of this first phase. Within the city, the project complements the long-term effort of the water supply project to ensure a sustainable groundwater supply because reduced quantity and concentration of surface water pollution would also reduce groundwater pollution. 6.10 The quantification of the economic benefits, which are largely environmental and health improvements, poses challenging analytical problems. By effectively removing subsidies for public utility services through the introduction of cost recovering tariff policies, the project not only supports the financial viability of the utility but also creates a stronger incentive for the efficient use of natural resources. PROJECT RISKS 6.26 The Bank-supported components of Shandong Environment Project form part of a broader strategy to secure environmental improvements in the XRB and enhanced well- being in Jinan and other project cities. Each component, if effectively implemented, would make a local contribution to the regional objective of the River Basin. However, to have a basinwide impact, the institutional innovations, the new approaches to pollution management, and demonstrated technologies of each of the components need to be replicated and complemented by sustained efforts across sectors and throughout the Basin. 6.27 Risks surrounding the project have therefore been divided into two broad categories: Short/Medium-Term Project Risks and Long-Term Strategic Risks. The former center around the immediate requirements of the project and the successful implementation of its components. The latter center around the overall impact of the project and relate to the sustainability of environmental improvements in the XRB. Short/Medium-Term Project Risks 6.28 The principal risks directly associated with the implementation of the project and the achievement of immediate project outputs can be grouped in environmental/ technical, financial and institutional issues (as summarized in Table 6.3 below). Long-Term Strategic Risks 6.29 Increase Environmental Pressures. Rapid economic and population growth, together with urbanization and industrialization, would continue to exercise environmental stress in the XRB. The carrying capacity of this ecological system is not yet fully understood nor is the impact of the current developments. This limits the ability of environmental management to give clear directions where, what type, and how much development is compatible with the natural environment and hence sustainable. 6.30 Areas of potential conflict include the push for industrial growth and need to protect the environment. Given the high returns on investments in a fast-growing economy, pollution reduction is competing for scarce capital with high opportunity costs. Only a systematic internalization of environmental externalities, as has started at a low level with the introduction of pollution charges, would resolve this apparent conflict by reflecting environment-related expenditures in the cost of doing business.

The economy of Shandong province, which has a 1995 population of some 87 million (32 percent urban) has grown rapidly over the past decade. The average annual growth rates of industrial output for TVIEs have been extremely high over the period 1990-95 (35.4 percent for township enterprises and 36.1 percent for village enterprises), much higher than that for state-owned enterprises (10.3 percent). TVIEs accounted for 63 percent of industrial output in 1995. 3. The Province has been one of the engines driving China's impressive economic growth over the past decade. This was primarily the result of substantial increases in agricultural productivity and industrial output. The latter took place to a large extent in Shandong's urban areas, particularly in Jinan, the capital city, and in the coastal cities of Qingdao, Weihai and Yantai. As a consequence, Jinan City, for example, suffers from coal emission pollution and acid rain from its abundance of industrial and residential boilers, which is exacerbated by the city's adverse topographic location, with over 200 inversions per year. Thus, in terms of air quality, Jinan ranks fourth among the 37 most environmentally stressed cities in China, constricting economic development, according to NEPA. Most other cities in the province are also failing to meet national standards on air pollution. The situation is especially alarming during the heating season (four months of the year). 4. Shandong Province has a rain-sparse climate with a large amount of the water supply derived from underground sources. Some of these aquifers are being increasingly polluted and reduced below replenishment amounts and domestic and industrial water has to be extracted from often polluted rivers, rainfed reservoirs or piped from distant water sources. Some cities, e.g., Jinan, Qingdao and Zibo, have to rely on costly water transmission from the Yellow River. At the same time, most rivers and lakes, especially the Xiaoqing River and Nanshi Lake, are heavily polluted, aggravating water shortages and restricting long-term economic development.

 - 69- ANNEX2 JINAN WASTEWATER SYSTEM 11. A Sewerage Master plan was originally prepared in 1983; this was updated in 1993 and provides the basis for the sewerage planning for the city. The urban area of Jinan is divided into seven catchments comprising Jiqi, Jiluo, Darning Lake, Liuhangtou, Huangtai Qili River, Wangsheren and Danjia catchments totaling about 140 km2 in area. 12. Existing Wastewater System. The existing sewer system comprises about 145 km of pipes in the catchments of Jiluo, Darning, Liuhangtou and Huangtai, in sizes between 300 and 1,500 mm diameter, mostly of concrete pipe construction, with small lengths of brick culverts and pipes. There are a number of pump stations, the most significant of which is the Juluo Bridge station, built in 1985, of about 220,000 m3/d design capacity, to lift sewage to the Jilan Wastewater Treatment Plant (SPT). This station is presently underutilized pending the construction of a new intercepting sewer to convey the flow to the SPT. 13. The present wastewater flow from all seven catchments in the city is about 680,000 m3/day, comprising about 30 percent domestic and 70 percent industrial flows. The existing sewerage system is partly combined and partly separate, and is seriously inadequate with large parts of the 145 km of main and secondary sewers not functioning satisfactorily, due to siltation, and blocking of the inverted siphons at river crossings. All wastewater flows discharge directly or indirectly into watercourses within the city or to the Xiaoqing River through existing sewers. As a result, the water quality in water courses and lakes within the city and the Xiaoqing River has deteriorated to below National Surface Water Class 5 Standard.
