 -95 - ANNEX6 ANNEX 6: LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT ACTION PLAN A. INTRODUCTION 1. The Shandong Environment Project (SDEP) has four components, located in the cities of Jinan, Weihai and Yantai and the XRB, which would involve land acquisition and resettlement/rehabilitation of affected persons. To facilitate mitigation of the adverse land acquisition-related impacts of the project and to comply with World Bank requirements, the concerned implementing agency has prepared a comprehensive Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) for each. 2. This annex describes the land acquisition and resettlement impacts of the project and discusses the frameworks developed by the Provincial and Municipal Governments for implementing and financing land acquisition and resettlement activities. Section B describes the land acquisition and social impacts of the project and the surveys carried out to verify impacts and identify resettlement issues. Section C sets out the implementation frameworks for Land Acquisition and Resettlement. Project implementation would commence in 1997 and continue to 2001. B. PROJECT IMPACTS 3. The following project components would require land acquisition and/or resettlement/rehabilitation of affected persons: Jinan City (a) Jinan Wastewater Collection; (b) Jinan Yellow River Water Supply; Weihai City (c) Weihai District Heating; and Yantai City (d) Yantai District Heating. One component includes resettlement that would be implemented under retroactively- financed contracts; the Jinan Wastewater Collection Project which has five annual stages, the first being implemented in 1996. The Weihai District Heating Project involved site
 - 96 - ANNEX6 acquisition and resettlement by the Weihai City Government in 1993 as part of suburban development. This would be implemented early in the project. In 1995, the site was chosen for the proposed Weihai No. 3 District Heating Plant, which is to be constructed as part of the project. Both of these components would have resettlement action plans which were submitted for review at appraisal, and found satisfactory. 4. Construction of the new project components requires land acquisition, resettlement of the affected persons, rehabilitation of businesses and livelihoods, and temporary disturbances during construction. In order to verify the impact of project components on the affected people and property, each implementing agency conducted a census of affected persons and properties and a socioeconomic sample survey of affected households, including attitudinal questions. Land Acquisition and Social Impacts 5. The data set out here represent the situation as of January 31, 1997. Most of the project components have been approved to the feasibility or preliminary engineering stages. The feasibility study approval sets the parameters for land acquisition, following which the implementing agencies can notify local government and the affected people. This enables detailed implementation planning and public consultation to proceed prior to project construction. 6. Land acquisition and social impacts are summarized as follows. (a) The amount of land to be permanently requisitioned is 992 hectares (14,879 mu); (b) 18 hectares (266 mu) of land would be affected temporarily during construction; (c) 300 hectares (4,500 mu) of farmland would be temporarily acquired after 2015 for sediment deposition. The land would be acquired gradually and would be returned to farmland after deposition is complete; (d) 667 households (2,120 people) need to have their housing relocated; (e) An estimated 4,574 farmers (including dependents) would have their livelihoods affected by land acquisition; (f) Investments in new land, agricultural improvements, sideline activities and enterprise employment is planned to restore livelihoods and incomes. Most of the agricultural persons can remain in agriculture through land redistribution, but some laborers may need to be provided with nonagricultural enterprise jobs; and
 - 97 - ANNEX6 (g) The project would affect 306 workers in 82 shops, until the shops can be relocated. The project would also affect 25 enterprises and 217 of their staff. Most staff would retain the same jobs after reconstruction; the remainder would be assisted in gaining new employment. Table 1 summarizes impacts for the four project subcomponents. 7. Detailed baseline socioeconomic surveys of the affected people have been completed by a local institute (Shandong University in Jinan). The baseline survey measures the income levels and standards of living of the affected persons before land acquisition and resettlement. This baseline survey forms the basis for comparing their income levels and standards of living as would be reported by the monitoring reports during project implementation. Minimization of Land Acquisition and Resettlement 8. The feasibility studies included an analysis of land acquisition and possible resettlement, as part of the identification of project options. While the selection between options was based on technical and economic criteria, the potential impact on project affected persons was also considered. (a) In Weihai, a project site was selected in the urban fringe which had already been zoned for industrial development. Land acquisition and resettlement had already been successfully completed by the city government in 1993. (b) In Yantai, the construction of the steam/heating pipeline has been routed next to roadways to avoid acquisition of housing. (c) In Jinan, the Wastewater Collection Project involves the construction of new underground sewers. These can be constructed along the road surface without affecting adjacent buildings. However, certain segments (12.4 km out of 50.9 km to be constructed) are along narrow roads that the city has planned to widen for better urban transport corridors and redevelopment of old city blocks. For these segments, a RAP has been prepared. (d) The Jinan Yellow River Water Supply Project involves the construction of a storage reservoir. The proposed site (Queshan Reservoir) is in a flood detention zone, and therefore affects fewer people and less arable farmland than any comparable sites near Jinan.
 - 98 - ANNEX6 C. FRAMEWORK FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT ACTIVITIES 9. Each RAP for the four project subcomponents with land acquisitions describes the framework and action plans for implementing the land acquisition and resettlement program. Each framework comprises the following elements: (a) Objectives and principles of land compensation and resettlement (b) Legal framework and resettlement policies (c) Resettlement institutions and agencies (d) Relocation of housing and compensation for personal assets (e) Compensation for lost income and plans for affected livelihoods (f) Costs and budget (g) Implementation schedule and arrangements for resettlement (h) Participation and consultation with affected persons (i) Redressal of grievance and appeals process (j) Monitoring and evaluation of RAP implementation. 10. The four RAPs covering the above components of the resettlement implementation framework have been prepared by the implementing agencies based on discussions with the concerned levels of government; the RAPs have been approved by the concerned municipal authorities, and would be implemented as an integral part of the project. The components of the framework for implementation are described below. Objectives and Principles of Resettlement 11. The main objective for each of the resettlement action plans is to ensure that the standards of living and income levels of all categories of affected persons are improved, or at least restored, after resettlement. The main principles for implementing the RAP are as follows. (a) Minimize land acquisition and resettlement as much as possible through choice of project components and changes in design and alignment. (b) Pay compensation for all structures at the replacement value of those structures. (c) Pay compensation for collective land to the local collective. This compensation would be used to increase the productive capacity of the collectives which in tum would rehabilitate incomes and livelihoods, and would not be used for any other purpose. (d) Agencies may arrange some jobs in nonagricultural enterprises for some persons whose lands are acquired. The majority of affected agricultural people would remain in agricultural livelihoods.
 -99 - ANNEX6 (e) All infrastructure, such as municipal roads, communication, lighting, sewerage, treatment work, etc. would be restored or replaced. The concerned implementing agency would fully compensate for reconstruction at replacement cost. (f) All affected enterprises would be compensated for any losses caused by the project (i.e., disruption of their property) including related assets, income and wages. (g) The implementing agencies would compensate persons affected by temporary construction impacts to ensure their standards of living are not adversely affected. (h) The implementing agencies would plan and carry out land acquisition and resettlement activities with the participation of affected persons and their representatives. (i) The affected persons or enterprises have avenues for redress of their grievances and if they are not satisfied with the outcome, they can appeal to higher authority and to civil courts. (j) For older people, special rehabilitation measures would be taken to ensure that elderly affected persons are able to maintain their standards of living. 12. The following guidelines and principles would be followed: (a) New houses of the affected persons would be of at least the same standard as the affected houses or equal to the minimum current standards, whichever is the greater; (b) All infrastructure affected would be restored or replaced at project cost; in a manner which maintains or improves the quality of services; (c) All affected shops would be assisted by the implementing agencies to resume operations at nearby locations; (d) Shop and enterprise workers would be provided with allowances equivalent to their salaries for the period of closure; and (e) Planning and implementation of the RAPs would be carried out with the participation of the affected persons and their representatives. Legal Framework and Resettlement Policies 13. The RAPs have been prepared based on the following laws, regulations and guidelines for land acquisition and resettlement issued by various authorities in China:
 -100 - ANNEX6 (a) The People's Republic of China Land Management Law (b) The People's Republic of China Land Management Implementation Act (c) Rules of Land Acquisition for National Construction (d) Land Administration Implementation Measures of Shandong Province (e) Municipal regulations for land requisition and resettlement compensation. 14. The implementation of land acquisition and resettlement program would be carried out in accordance with the specific provisions of each subcomponent's RAP. Compensation/Resettlement Policies for Different Categories of Project Impacts 15. The following categories of project impacts were assessed during the census survey of affected persons and properties: (a) Permanent land acquisition of collective land (b) Temporary disturbance/occupation of land during construction (c) Loss of housing (d) Households losing agricultural land and income (e) Relocation of shops and small businesses (f) Partial impacts on enterprises (g) Loss of standing crops (h) Indirect impacts in the disturbance zone. 16. The RAPs provide full details of housing allocation and reconstruction options. The compensation and/or resettlement policies for the above categories of impacts are as follows. (a) Permanent Land Acquisition of Collective Land. The implementing agency would pay compensation to the affected local government. The rates have been provided in the RAP. The local governments would use compensation payments to restore the productive capacity of the affected villages through the development of agriculture-based and nonagriculture- based economic activities. (b) Temporary Disturbance/Occupation of Land During Construction. The implementing agency would compensate for temporary use based on loss of net income from the land, including returns to labor. With this compensation, the village officials would arrange the economic rehabilitation and provide compensation directly to the persons temporarily affected. (c) Loss of Housing. Persons losing government-owned or private apartments and houses would have the options of: (i) moving into a community-built house of the same standard as previous house, without any extra payment; or
 -101- ANNEX 6 (ii) constructing a new house upon payment of compensation at replacement value for the affected house or structure. No deductions would be made for depreciation. (d) Households Losing Agricultural Land and Income. All households that lose income by land acquisition would be given the option of new land, investment in other agricultural or sideline activities, or full-time jobs in nonagricultural enterprises. (e) Relocation of Shops and Small Businesses. The implementing agency and municipal land departments would assist business to find alternative plots for continuing their businesses. Implementing agencies would compensate such businesses for the replacement cost of the shop, relocation costs and losses in net income during the period when their business is closed. (f) Partial Impacts on Enterprises. The implementing agency would pay the cost of restoration at full replacement value as compensation. (g) Loss of Standing Crops. Standing crops compensation would be paid directly to the affected farmers at the full market value of comparable mature crops at harvest. (h) Indirect Impacts in the Disturbance Zone. Indirect impacts due to the construction of the project, on structures, businesses or people in the disturbance zone would be compensated for physical loss at the full Teplacement rates and/or net income loss. Structures needing repairs would be compensated fully for the repairs. If any houses need to be relocated due to such impact, they would be treated on the same lines as houses affected by permanent land acquisition. 17. In case it were found that the standards of living of any category of affected persons have not been restored after relocation or resettlement, the implementing agency would be responsible to take additional measures to ensure that the entitlements stipulated by the RAP are achieved. Tables 2 to 5 summarize the categories of affected people and their relevant entitlement, for each subcomponent. Restoration of Household Incomes 18. Most of the agricultural land to be acquired involves the Jinan Yellow River Water Supply Project. Households (villages) that lose a small share of their household incomes (less than 25 percent) can be allocated more land within the village and provided compensation to improve production output on unaffected land or nonland-based income generating activities. Households (villages) that lose most of their incomes (more than 75 percent) would be provided new land in a host village and some laborers would be eligible for full-time nonagricultural jobs in enterprises. Households (villages) that lose a significant share of their household incomes (25 to 75 percent) would restore livelihoods
 -102- ANNEX6 and incomes through a combination of the above strategies. The income generation schemes would guarantee that after resettlement household incomes are higher than present income levels. During the transition period, food and income subsidies would be provided by the implementing agency to maintain living standards. The transition period would be minimized by proper scheduling of resettlement and project construction activities. Job training would be provided for households that undertake new income- generation activities. Also, such affected households would be eligible for preferential policies that would be promulgated by the Jinan Municipal Government. Resettlement Institutions and Agencies 19. The Shandong Provincial Project Management Office (SPPMO) has vested overall responsibility for coordination of planning and implementation of resettlement activities with the project. SPPMO and the Municipal project offices in Jinan, Yantai and Weihai are responsible for coordinating resettlement activities. The actual planning and implementation of resettlement would be carried out by the borrower implementing agencies, together with the township/district and village governments. In addition to these, the main departments, bureaus and agencies responsible for various aspects of resettlement planning, implementing, coordinating and monitoring resettlement activities are the following: (a) The Planning Administration Office in each project city (b) The Shandong Provincial and Municipal Land administration Bureau for Jinan, Yantai and Weihai (c) The Labor Bureau for Jinan, and Yantai (d) The Shandong Provincial and Municipal Urban and Rural Construction Commissions for Jinan, Yantai and Weihai (e) Shandong Yellow River Management Office. Costs and Budget 20. The costs of RAP implementation is part of the overall budget of the project. The annual requirement of funds would be included in the annual investment plan for the project. The base cost of land acquisition and resettlement is estimated to be approximately Y 231.6 million ($27.9 million). The cost estimates by subcomponent are shown in Table 6. 21. The cost estimates would be adjusted based on the actual inflation rate. Physical contingencies of 15 percent of the cost estimates have been budgeted. Each borrower implementing agency is responsible for provision of adequate funds to carry out RAP implementation. Cost overruns, if any, would be borne by each such agency.

In order to ensure that the affected persons have avenues for redressing their grievances, detailed procedures for redressal of grievances have been established. Many grievances can be handled by the implementing agency but if this not successful, an affected person can initiate the formal process. First, the affected person could lodge a grievance with the township Land Management Office, to which the Office should respond within 15 days. Second, if the person is not satisfied, an appeal would be made to a department within the District Government within a specified time. Third, if still unsatisfied, the affected person could appeal to a department within the Municipal Government for redressing the grievance. Finally, an appeal can be lodged with the People's court within 15 days of receiving the decision from the Municipal level. The grievance could be for any aspect of the RAP program, including rates of compensation. Grievance mechanisms would be included in the Resettlement Information Booklet. Monitoring would be carried out based on the provisions of the RAP.  -113 - ANNEX 7 ANNEX 7: ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT SUMMARY Introduction 1. Shandong is located in the northeast of China and is bordered to the north by Hebei Province, to the south by Anhui and Jiangsu Provinces, to the east by the Bohai Sea and to the west by Hebei and Henan Provinces. The province covers an area of 157,000 km2 and has a population of 87 million (1995 data), of which the urban population accounted for 32 percent. The population growth rate is 0.38 percent. Jinan, the provincial capital, has a total population of 5.37 million, of which the urban area population is 2.43 million, and is one of the major industrial centers of the province, accounting for about 10 percent of its GDP. 2. Industrial sectors represented in Jinan include steel, machinery, metals, textiles, food, chemicals and pharmaceuticals. Industrial growth in Jinan has been rapid, with output rising in real terms by a factor of 2.5 between 1986 and 1994. Other major cities in Shandong include Qingdao, Dongying, Zibo, Weihai and Yantai. Each of these cities has a per capita GDP in the highest 10 percent of all cities in China, although that of Jinan is the lowest of the major cities in Shandong. The rapid growth in the major cities in Shandong has resulted in serious environmental problems, in particular in relation to air pollution. 3. The Xiaoqing River Basin (XRB) covers an area of approximately 16,992 km2 and a population in the order of 9 million, some 10 percent of the provincial total. The basin is an important agricultural and industrial production base for Shandong Province, accounting for one-fifth of the provincial GDP. 4. Rapid industrial growth in the Xiaoqing basin has led to a major decline in water quality, and pollution in the Basin poses threats to health and to economic development. Increasingly there are reports of unsafe drinking water, and contamination of Laizhou Bay threatens the key seafood industry of Shandong, to which there has already been substantial damage. 5. Weihai and Yantai are both located in the northeastern part of the Shandong peninsula on the Yellow Sea coast. Weihai has a population of 2.4 million, of which 420,000 are urban; the urban center includes industrial areas and the suburban population is mainly engaged in agriculture, fisheries and aquaculture. A high-tech industrial zone is planned for the southern part of the city. Yantai is an important port city with a population of 6.3 million including 1.4 million in the urban area. The city is rich in natural resources and has major outputs of gold, talcum, marble and a range of agricultural products, particularly apples, of which it is among the leading producers in
 -114- ANNEX7 China. It is an important tourism center and has major sea fishery and aquaculture operations. Administrative and Institutional Framework 6. The State Environmental Protection Committee (SEPC) is the highest level of authority on environmental policy and includes the State Council and heads of all relevant ministries and agencies. NEPA functions as the secretariat of SEPC and is responsible for all aspects of environmental policy although it shares authority with other agencies for certain natural resources. NEPA sets overall policies and regulations governing the provincial and municipal EPBs, and implementation of environmental policy is through the municipal and provincial EPBs, who are responsible for the maintenance of environmental quality. 7. The Shandong Provincial Govermnent has accorded priority to the cleanup of the XRB and, accordingly, established in 1994 the Xiaoqing River Basin Environmental Management Commission to develop and implement a long-term strategy to improve the condition of the river. In addition to pollution control, the strategy addresses flood control, irrigation, navigation, aquatic production and tourism. Project Description 8. The proposed project comprises a total of six components as follows: (a) Jinan Wastewater Collection System-construction of about 38 km of trunk and secondary sewer networks to permit utilization of the capacity (220 000 m3/day) of the existing wastewater treatment plant; (b) Jinan Water Supply-facilities for abstraction of water (up to 9.6 M3! second) from the existing irrigation intake on the Yellow River, storage in a new reservoir of capacity 46 million m3 and to transfer to existing water treatment plants; (c) Weihai District Heating-construction of a new CHP plant of capacity 24 MW electricity and 120 MW heat, about 17 km of steam and 13 km of hot water distribution networks, and 10 heat exchange stations; (d) Yantai District Heating-provision of 30 km of heating network, 42 heat exchange stations and peak boiler plant of capacity about 112 MW; (e) Xiaoqing Basin Industrial Pollution Control Subloan Facility; and (f) Technical Assistance and Training. Of these components only (a) to (d) involve physical works in the immediate term and are therefore covered by this Environmental Assessment (EA). Separate EA reports were
 -115 - ANNEX7 prepared for each component, which then were synthesized into a comprehensive project- wide EA report. Baseline Data 9. Shandong is the second largest province in China and has the third largest aggregate GDP; the per capita GDP is Y 5,747, approximately 1.5 times the national average and the seventh highest of the provinces (excluding the three province status cities of Beijing, Shanghai and Tianjin). Contributions to the GDP from agriculture, industry and the tertiary sector are 20.2, 47.4 and 32.4 percent, respectively. The gross agricultural output of Shandong is the highest of any province in China and the gross industrial output ranks second after that of Jiangsu. 10. Some 64 percent of the area of the province is mountainous or hilly and forest cover is 20 percent. The province includes eight major lakes and nine major rivers, of which the most important is the Huang He (Yellow River), which in the western part of the province forms the boundary with Hebei. Water resources in the province average 200 m3/capita. 11. The energy needs of the province are met almost entirely by coal, which is of variable quality, with sulfur contents sometimes in excess of 2.5 percent. As a result Shandong has the highest emissions (in mass terms) of SO2 of any of the provinces in China. Climate 12. The climate of Shandong is classified as temperate monsoon; rainfall is low, annual averages being between 550 and 950 mm, and concentrated in summer. Annual average temperatures range between 11 and 14 C, temperatures decreasing from northeast to southwest. The coldest month is January, with average temperatures ranging from -4 to 1 C, and the hottest month is July, with average temperatures between 24 and 27 C. The average number of frost-free days ranges from 180 to 220 per year. 13. The Xiaoqing River originates in the west of Jinan, the Provincial capital, and flows a distance of 237 km, passing through a total of 5 cities and 18 towns, villages and counties, before discharging to the Bohai Sea in Laizhou Bay in eastern Shandong. Average annual rainfall in the basin is 619.5 mm, concentrated principally in the wet season (July to September), which accounts for 50 to 60 percent of the total annual rainfall. The mean flow in the Xiaoqing is 40.3 m3/second; much of the rainfall in the basin recharges the shallow and deep aquifers that underlie the region. 14. Both Weihai and Yantai have a continental monsoon climate, with annual average temperatures of 12.3 and 13 C, respectively. Annual rainfall in the two cities averages 777 mm and 613 mm, respectively, the majority of which in each case occurs in summer. The prevailing wind direction in Weihai is northwest and between south-southwest and
 -116- ANNEX7 west-southwest in Yantai; average annual wind velocities are 5.6 m/second and 3.6 m/ second, respectively. Water and Air Quality Standards 15. The water quality standards appropriate in respect of water quality in the Xiaoqing basin are those of the national Environmental Quality Standard for Surface Waters (GB 3838-88). The National Standard defines water quality standards applicable to five different classes of surface water with designated uses ranging from national nature reserves (Class I); municipal water supply and fisheries protection (Class II); water supply after treatment and recreation involving contact (e.g., swimming) (Class III); industrial water supply and noncontact recreation (Class IV) to agriculture and industrial cooling water (Class V). The mainstream Xiaoqing River is currently very heavily polluted, with concentrations of some pollutants being more than 10 times the maximum concentration allowed by the least stringent classification, Class V. 16. The national ambient air quality standards (GB 3095-82) specify different air quality standards for different classifications of land use. The standards specify maximum annual average, maximum daily average and maximum instantaneous concentrations of SO2, TSP and NO, for three categories of land use; (a) Class I: Tourist, historic, conservation and sanitarium areas; (b) Class II: Urban residential, cultural and rural areas and places of historic interest; (c) Class III: Industrial districts and heavy traffic areas. Class I areas are designated by the State Government and Class II and III areas by locals government. 17. Xiaoqing River Basin Water Quality. Industrial development in the Xiaoqing basin has caused a major decline in water quality, and the river is now in effect a wastewater canal. The present total wastewater flow discharged to the Xiaoqing and its tributaries is approximately 12.5 m3/second, of which 7.5m3/second are derived from industry. Thus the dilution available for this wastewater is only a factor of about 3 on even an annual average basis and much lower during the dry season. As a result concentrations of COD exceed 200 mg/l, some 10 times even the least stringent Class V standard, and dissolved oxygen is present only at the source and in minimal concentrations in the lower reaches. A range of toxic or persistent organic chemicals have been identified in the mainstream Xiaoqing. 18. The main sources of pollution of the Xiaoqing are industrial wastewater discharges and urban wastewater from a number of cities and counties, principally Jinan, Zibo, Binzhou and Weifang, and from the Qilu petrochemicals complex, which is located close to Zibo but discharges wastewater via a 60 km pipeline into the Xiaoqing close to
 -117- ANNEX7 the outlet to Laizhou bay. The pollution loads to the Xiaoqing are shown in Table 1 below. The industrial wastewater COD load, in total accounting for approximately 85 percent of the overall total load, is dominated by the loads associated with wastewaters from two sectors of industry. The major polluting industry sector is the manufacture of paper using straw as the raw material from which the pulp is produced. This sector generates an aggregate COD load of approximately 211,000 tons/year, some 63 percent of the total industrial COD load to the Xiaoqing and more than 50 percent of the overall total COD load. The other important polluting sector is food and beverage production, pollution from which is dominated by wastewaters from wineries and distilleries. The sector in total accounts for 27 percent of the industrial COD load and 23 percent of the overall load. Thus, these two sectors in aggregate account for more than 75 percent of the overall load to the Xiaoqing and its tributaries and clearly these sectors must be a key focus of any pollution control program for the Xiaoqing basin. 20. These overall COD loads are extremely high, given the very limited water flows in the Xiaoqing. The total COD load of 394,036 tons/year is equivalent to an average concentration (based on the annual average flow of 40.3 m3/second and neglecting self- purification) in the order of 300 mg/l. Such concentrations are understood to be consistent with those measured in the upper reaches of the river in the Jinan region. 21. A major factor affecting water quality in the upper reaches of the Xiaoqing is the inadequate sewerage system in Jinan. A major wastewater treatment plant (with a capacity of 220,000 m3/day) has been constructed, but this treatment capacity cannot be utilized because of sewerage system deficiencies, which means that all Jinan wastewater flows remain untreated. 22. For the purposes of water quality management in the basin, the Xiaoqing River has been divided into four main reaches-Jinan; Zibo-Binzhou; Dongying; and Weifang, and 17 river sections. The former two reaches constitute the nontidal portion of the river,
 -118 - ANNEX7 a total river length of 166 km, and the latter two (a total of 71 km) the tidal estuary. The long-term (2000-10) water quality objectives for the Xiaoqing are as follows: Water Quality Classification Reach (GB 3838-88) Jinan IV Zibo-Binzhou III Dongying-Weifang II 23. Shandong EPB has made estimates of the assimilative capacity of the Xiaoqing, based on a water quality model developed by the Shandong Environmental Protection Design Institute (SEPDI) for dry-season flow conditions. Based on these estimates, the EPB has also made preliminary estimates of the degrees of reduction in COD loads entering the river that would be necessary to achieve the water quality objectives. The projected and allowable COD loads for the year 2010 are as follows: 2010 COD Load to River Reach (tons/year) Jinan Zibo-Binzhou Dongying-Weifang Total Projected /a 114,066 35,020 65,540 245,153 Allowable 8,424 2,662 3,277 14,363 La Taking account of self purification and deposition in tributaries and lakes, the benefit of this may in practice be less than expected because of resuspension of polluted material from the river bed during the first rains following dry periods. 24. These figures imply a need to reduce loads by more than 90 percent by 2010. In practice, as may be seen from Table 1 above, the present total point source COD loads before treatment are already in the order of 400,000 tons/year. 25. The magnitude of the water pollution problems and the limited water resources of the XRB highlight the importance of control of wastewater discharges on the basis of pollution loads rather than solely on simple concentration-based discharge standards. This has been recognized in the case of the Xiaoqing Basin for some years and the basin was selected by NEPA in 1987 to participate along with 17 cities (including Jinan and Zibo) in the trial implementation of a discharge permit system. 26. This has had limited effectiveness, however, because the permit system adopted by the Shandong EPB was goal rather than capacity-based. The EPB established short- and medium-term goals for reductions in pollution discharges in Jinan, Zibo and the Qilu Petrochemical Industrial Area based on the pollution loads from these areas. A greater reduction was required of areas that contributed a greater proportion of the total load, where economic conditions were better or where technical resources were available. In
 -119- ANNEX7 particular, 37 enterprises discharging more than 85 percent of the COD load from Jinan were required by the Jinan EPB to register the details of their discharges. 27. The system has not achieved the desired effect for a number of other reasons, including its application only to existing discharges. As a consequence pollution loads have continued to increase in spite of the fact that wastewater volumes and COD loads discharged per unit of industrial output (at constant prices) each declined by more than a factor of 3 between 1986 and 1994. 28. It has also been appreciated that to achieve pollution load reduction targets it would necessary for industry to change to cleaner production processes. To implement management strategies for pollution prevention and control in the Xiaoqing basin, the Shandong Provincial Government has issued an order that seriously polluting industries would be ordered to close, cease production or comply with pollution control within deadlines. This pollution control may take the form either of end-of-pipe treatment or the introduction of cleaner production technologies involving lower levels of pollution. 29. Weihai and Yantai Air Quality. Weihai was designated the first Chinese "Clean City" in 1990, but atmospheric pollution is increasing as a result of the rising use of coal for domestic purposes and increasingly as a fuel for industry. Total coal consumption in Weihai is currently in the order of 900,000 tons/year; and typical sulfur contents of the coal are in the order of 1.7 percent. Apart from a small area in the city center air quality in Weihai is Class II or better and that in the southern part of the city is Class I. However, it is expected that the proposed industrial development in the high- tech zone would cause a decline in air quality in this area to Class II and also a further decline in the city center. 30. Although more than 95 percent of the population of the city proper of Yantai use gas as a domestic fuel, consumption of coal (with sulfur contents typically in the order of 1.2 percent) exceeds 1.5 million tons/year, the majority of which is consumed by industry. As a result air quality (in terms of SO2 concentrations) is currently Class III in an area of about 18 km2 and fails to meet even this standard in a further 12 km2 in the center of the city. Consideration of Alternatives 31. For all components the concepts represent the only practical solutions. Where a range of detailed options was available, the proposals adopted were those meeting the required objectives at least cost. Environmental Benefits 32. The Project involves components aimed at substantially reducing discharges of pollution to the XRB and to the atmosphere. Accordingly, the balance of the environmental impact of the project is substantially positive and the positive
 -120 - ANNEX7 environmental benefits greatly outweigh the negative impacts. Environmental benefits of the project components are described below. 33. Jinan Wastewater Collection. The provision of enhanced wastewater collection facilities in Jinan would result in the collection and subsequent treatment of a wastewater flow of 220,000 m3/day, some 46 percent of the total urban wastewater flow. Treatment of this flow would reduce the COD load from Jinan urban wastewater by 32,120 tons/year, some 20 percent of the total COD load to the Xiaoqing from the Jinan region, with substantial reductions in the loads of other pollutants. 34. This component would reduce the COD concentration in the Xiaoqing downstream of Jinan by almost 100 mg/l (approximately 45 percent), albeit only to a level in excess of 130 mg/I, still more than six times even the Class V standard. 35. Jinan Water Supply Intake. This component would sustain the use of the Yellow River as a water resource for Jinan during the dry season and would reduce the dependence on groundwater. Groundwater is currently being abstracted at an unsustainable rate in terms of its recharge; as a result the quality of groundwater is declining, and the continued abstraction of groundwater in Jinan, with the associated reduction in groundwater levels, threatens the flow of water in the springs for which Jinan is famous. The scheme would yield a supply of approximately 400,000 m3/day, resulting in an improvement in the quality of water entering supply serving a population of some 1 million. 36. Weihai District Heating. The proposed No. 3 Thermal Power Plant in Weihai would provide district heating and process steam for the developing high-tech industrial zone in the south of the city, thereby substituting 29 existing boilers and avoiding the provision of any new boilers and household heating stoves in the zone. This would result in significant savings in coal consumption as a consequence of both economies of scale and enhanced thermal efficiency of heat supply, with associated benefits of reduced emissions of SO2 and TSP. These emissions would be reduced still further by the fact that the combustion process employed at the power plant is a fluidized-bed system with injection of limestone to remove SO2; in addition, the impact of the emissions at ground level is further reduced by their discharge through a tall (100 m) stack compared with the existing discharges from independent boilers and stoves at very close to ground level. 37. As a consequence of these reductions in emissions, there would be significant improvements in air quality both in the high-tech industrial zone and elsewhere in the city. The environmental improvements associated with the project are shown in Table 2. 38. Yantai District Heating. The proposed conversion of the Yellow Sea and Bohai Sea Thermal Power Co. Ltd. power plant to a CHP system for extending district heating in Yantai would replace about 200 existing boilers and 64,000 household stoves and avoid the provision of any new such facilities. Coal consumption in the city is expected to increase by almost 25 percent between 1994 and 2000, with associated worsening of air quality.

Although the impact of the project is on balance substantially positive, nevertheless, negative impacts have been identified in the EA process for all components that require detailed analysis and mitigation measures. The principal impacts for each of the individual project components are described below. Jinan Wastewater Collection 41. Construction Phase. The construction impact of the Jinan wastewater collection project would be almost entirely during the construction phase. Excavation for the installation of about 38 km of sewers would result in substantial quantities of spoil material; however, the majority of this material would be used in other construction projects in Jinan. A detailed spoil disposal plan would be prepared. Other impacts of the project during construction include noise, dust and disruption to traffic and other urban services. The impact would be reduced to the minimum practicable by controls on construction practice. 42. Sludge Disposal. The principal objective of the wastewater collection component is to facilitate the effective use of the existing wastewater treatment plant, which is currently limited by sewerage system deficiencies. When operating at design throughput, the wastewater treatment plant would generate a total of some 53 tons (as dry solids) of
 -122 - ANNEX7 sludge daily. Sludge would be appropriately treated and safely disposed principally through codisposing to municipal sanitary landfills. Jinan Water Supply Intake 43. Resettlement. This project requires substantial land acquisition, both temporary and permanent, totaling in excess of 8 km2 and resettlement of a total of 1,186 persons. These issues are discussed in detail in Annex 6. 44. Downstream Impact. The proposed mode of operation of the facility envisages an abstraction of 9.65 m3/second during the highest flow period of July-September and of 8.65 m3/second during the remainder of the year. At some times of the year, it may not be possible to sustain such an abstraction rate without adverse impact upon downstream water uses or water quality. Under such conditions, abstraction rates would reduce or abstraction would be suspended. 45. Construction Phase. During construction, there would be a number of impacts such as noise, dust, construction traffic and disruptions to land use and services; these would be minimized, wherever possible, by using environmentally responsive construction specifications, controls on construction practice through adequate site supervision and by carefully scheduling construction operations. In particular, there would be disruption to the road from Jinan to Dezhou; a temporary replacement road would be constructed. 46. Seepage Control. Groundwater in the area of the proposed reservoir is relatively shallow and there is concern that leakage from the base of the reservoir could result in rising groundwater levels and possibly even waterlogging of soils. In view of the high evaporation rates, there is concern also in respect of salinization of soils. Two methods of leakage control are therefore proposed. The reservoir would be lined with geotextile membranes with appropriate blockwork protection and, in addition, a system of leakage collection and discharge ditches would be constructed. 47. Dredged Material Disposal. The Yellow River carries high silt loads, particularly during high flow periods; silt loads contained in the water abstracted have been estimated at almost 1.2 million m3 annually. Accordingly, it would be necessary to remove silt from the water before it enters the reservoir to avoid capacity loss by siltation, and a dedicated sedimentation basin is provided for this purpose. This sedimentation basin would require dredging at intervals to sustain its operation. The dredged material would be moved to a stockyard area where it would be kept moist to prevent dispersal of fine sand material and covered to generate new agricultural areas. The Yellow River Basin authorities and JMSC have built up extensive experience with the removal, handling, and environmentally safe management of this silt. 48. Control of Eutrophication. Data for nutrient (nitrogen and phosphorus) concentrations in the Yellow River indicate that the reservoir could be eutrophic. Concentrations in the River are particularly high during the period when flows increase as
 -123 - ANNEX7 a result of the first rains after prolonged dry periods (particularly at the beginning of the wet season). It is proposed, as far as possible (resource considerations permitting), to control nutrient loads entering the reservoir by restricting abstractions under these flow conditions. In the reservoir, optimum levels for nitrogen and phosphorus are determined to be 0.6 and 0.04 mg/l, respectively. Weihai and Yantai District Heating 49. Air Pollution Control. The principal impact of the district heating components is the generation of boiler slag and fly ash residues. The ash contents of the coals used in the cities are typically about 25 percent. Although in each case there is a substantial net decrease in coal consumption, in all cases there would be a concentration of coal consumption at a large facility rather than small-scale use at a large number of small individual boilers and stoves. Thus, large amounts of residues would require disposal from these facilities, and in the case of the Jinan and Weihai, the residues would contain the products of flue gas desulfurization. It is proposed to use all residues from the power plants and boilers in the manufacture of building materials at enterprises located nearby. To minimize problems of dust during storage and transport of these residues, conveyors would be covered and stockpiles would be kept moist. 50. SPG would, in parallel, undertake boiler upgrading and energy efficiency programs to reduce SO2 and TSP emissions in Weihai and Yantai. This is expected to contribute to overall air quality improvement. 51. The power stations and boilers are located in urban areas, and in some cases, it would be necessary to provide noise insulation and attenuation measures to ensure compliance with urban noise standards. The construction of the distribution systems for steam and hot water would generate spoil from excavation. However, given the general pipework sizes it is not expected that quantities of excess spoil would be substantial. 52. The impacts and their associated mitigation measures are listed in Table 3.

 -135- ANNEX12 ANNEX 12: ENVIRONMENTAL POLLUTION PREVENTION AND CONTROL Introduction 1. Shandong's industrial growth of nearly 17 percent per year over the past five years has been accompanied by increasing discharges of wastewater, solid waste, and air pollutants. An increasingly strict environmental regulatory regime has held waste discharges below the overall growth rate, but wastewater and air polluting discharges have still grown some 7 percent per year. Naturally, the impact of this growth varies with location, industrial concentration and type of effluent. The candidate cities for the Shandong Environment Project have the largest concentrations of industry, and some of the most highly polluting, in the province: Jinan and Zibo industry discharges to the Xiaoqing River, which is experiencing declining absorptive capacity, virtually rendering it unusable for agriculture or fisheries. 2. In the province as a whole, the pulp and paper industry remains the worst polluter, responsible for 58 percent of all industrial water pollution and providing 20 of the top 45 polluters. Next comes the alcohol industry, with 19 percent of wastewater, and 1 1 of the top 45 polluters. The metallurgy industry ranks third, with one company representing 3 percent of total industrial pollution. Other top polluters include a variety of chemical and refinery plants. 3. The XRB provides one measure of the relative impact of environmental pollution. The water pollution in the river is mainly caused by organic pollutants, with serious consequences for beneficial uses of the river. The point source pollution in the Basin represents 94.8 percent of the total pollution load. About 85.4 percent is from industries and 14.6 percent from urban sewage. The nonpoint pollution, while only 5.2 percent of the pollution load, is nevertheless still significant. 4. Analysis of pollution sources and abatement costs in Shandong demonstrates the relatively low cost of addressing some pollutants at source. A significant reduction of industrial COD, for example, is estimated to cost about Y 858 million investment. Some 281,400 kg COD would be removed by treating 173 million m3 wastewater a year. The Environmental Pollution Control component of the project addresses these industrial point sources. 5. The component relies on a two-part strategy: (a) lending for a number of smaller pollution prevention and control investments through a Xiaoqing River Basin Subloans
 -136- ANNEX12 Facility (XRBSL), to be capitalized at $10 million, utilizing $5 million of proceeds of the Bank loan, and an equal amount of local currency; and (b) action plans for the cleanup of the Basin. This annex discusses in turn each part of the strategy. Environmental Policy in Shandong Province 6. In May 1988, the Implementation Plan for Pollution Prevention and Treatment in the XRB was approved by the Provincial People's Congress Standing Committee. It prioritized four actions: * treating 31 high-polluting enterprises; * construction of two municipal wastewater treatment plants in Jinan and Zibo; * improving water quality by transferring water from the Yellow River and Mada Lake; v providing good quality drinking water in the seriously polluted areas. So far 12 of the 31 enterprises have treated their wastewater discharge, the wastewater treatment plant in Zibo (140,000 tons/day) is completed and in Jinan (220,000 tons/day) is nearly completed, the Yellow River is contributing, on average, 1.5 m3/second of water and drinking water is provided now to 360,000 people by drilling 237 deep wells and building 10 oxidation ponds. 7. At the end of 1995 and during 1996, Shandong Province issued new regulations to strengthen water pollution prevention and control: 3 Notice on the Establishment of a Special Fund for Controlling Pollution Generated from Pulp and Paper Enterprises, Breweries and Distilleries, No. 19. This document requires enterprises producing pulp and paper, monosodium glutamate (MSG), citric acid and alcoholic beverages to contribute to a special fund, based on their annual production output, as long as the concentration of pollutants in their wastewater exceeds the national standards; * Decision on Strengthening Water Pollution Prevention and Control, No. 31. It sets a timetable for wastewater discharge control, indicating that by the end of 1997 the key polluting industries located along the river basin should be in compliance with national standards and by the end of 2000, all industrial pollution sources should meet the standards; and, * Provisional Measures for Collecting the Urban Wastewater Fee in Shandong Province, No. 52. This document mandates the collection of urban wastewater treatment fees from working units and individuals, located in the service area,
 -137- ANNEX 12 to cover the construction, operating and maintenance costs of the centralized treatment plants. Pollution Fee Collection and Use in Shandong Province 8. As one means of providing technical and financial assistance to help polluters to bring their discharges within the pennitted loads, a 1982 Chinese environmental law provided for the establishment of provincial, municipal and county environmental funds financed by pollution levies. The levies originally provided grants for pollution control investments in industrial and municipal projects, and 20 percent was earmarked for EPB environmental monitoring and enforcement activities. A 1988 amendment to the law stipulated that up to 50 percent of the fund income was to be loaned rather than granted to enterprises in Shandong, and in 1990 SPG ruled that the fund could no longer provide grants to industry, thereby enhancing the Polluter Pays Principle. By the end of 1994, the total amount of loans made to enterprises was Y 449 million, implementing 1,064 projects for pollution treatment and control. 9. In Shandong, municipal and county EPBs collect pollution levy fees, while the provincial, municipal and county EPBs jointly plan fee collection and utilization. The finance bureau at each level of government holds the revenue collected, and disburses it via local branches of the People's Construction Bank of China according to a fund allocation plan provided by the EPBs. 10. Fee rates have been established for wastewater discharges, waste gas emissions, solid waste disposal and noise pollution. Fee collections rose from Y 19 million in 1991 to over Y 33 million in 1995, with over 70 percent of the collected fees used for industrial pollution control and the remainder financing the EPBs' environmental monitoring and enforcement work. Environmental Policy for the Xiaoqing River Basin 11. In 1988, a special organization was established by SPG-the Xiaoqing River Basin Environmental Management Commission. It has no office of its own, but under its leadership are two organizations with full-time staff: * the Xiaoqing River Basin Environment Leadership Group within the Provincial Planning Commission, whose tasks are to compile comprehensive plans for environmental management in the river basin and to coordinate between the government agencies involved in the implementation of these plans; * the Xiaoqing River Basin Environmental Management Office within SEPB, whose tasks, within the river basin, are to develop environmental regulations, monitoring and inspecting environmental programs, enforcement and participating in the development of comprehensive plans for environmental management.
 -138- ANNEX 12 12. As a result of a law (Luzhengfa, No. 42, 1995) passed by SPG, some companies have been closed, while 45 provincial enterprises and 55 enterprises below the provincial level have been ordered to reduce their emissions before the end of 1997. The estimated impact is a reduction of daily discharge of COD of 220 tons. Pollution Fee Collection and Use in the Xiaoqing River Basin 13. For the Xiaoqing River Basin area, the money collected from pollution levies is shared between 24 accounts: 5 municipal EPBs, 18 county EPBs and the provincial EPB, where it is mixed with levies from all other parts of the province. Per year, the 23 sublevel EPBs deal with a total of Y 130 million used specifically for pollution control while, at provincial level, Y 40 million (1995) are available for the whole province. The pollution levy funds of the municipalities along the river basin, that is Jinan, Zibo, Weifang, Dongying and Binzhou, total Y 136 million. Y 76 million is used for wastewater treatment. 14. The Special Fund for Controlling Pollution Generated from Pulp and Paper Enterprises, Breweries and Distilleries, mentioned above, would only contribute to pollution control investments. The total amount that is collected by the Light Industries Bureaus and the TVIE Management Bureaus would be returned to enterprises. The fees are Y 100 per ton of pulp; Y 50 per ton of alcohol, MSG and citric acid; and Y 20 per ton of beer based on annual output. 15. Bank Group Experience in China with Environmental Funds. China still has limited experience with environmental loan funds. The Bank Group has supported the establishment of such funds under seven different projects and three of them have been in operation for at least one year. Compared to domestically financed funds, the Bank Group-assisted funds have been found to have the following advantages: (a) they typically provide a stronger framework for management, including organization, staffing and operation regulations, and consciously seek links with other environmental protection management measures such as the promotion of pollution prevention programs; (b) they institute rigorous requirements and procedures for project preparation and appraisal, ensuring a higher project success rate; and (c) they train staff of the fund offices in the technical and financial areas. 16. One disadvantage of Bank-supported funds is that the more rigorous appraisal procedures have been expensive compared to the size of the typical loan, which has been under $1 million. Due regard needs to be given to modifications of the appraisal procedures to bring down costs while maintaining quality.
 -139- ANNEX12 Xiaoqing River Basin Subloans Facility 17. The purpose of Xiaoqing River Basin Subloans Facility (XRBSL) is to strengthen the existing Shandong pollution prevention and control program with a technically and institutionally sustainable financing mechanism. The subloans would primarily assist small-scale industrial enterprises within the Xiaoqing River Basin to control pollution through waste minimization measures, modifications or renovations to existing plants to reduce waste outputs, clean technology, or recycling waste generated during production. Industrial upgrading projects designed to reduce the amount of pollutant discharge and to save natural resources and energy, commercial waste recovery services and wastewater treatment plants would also be considered by this facility. SEPB has identified a priority list of Basin enterprises, and others among the 45 most polluting enterprises, to receive preferential access to XRBSL. 18. Organization and Financing of XRBSL. XRBSL would be a self-accounting govermnent facility, with an initial capital equivalent of Y 83 million. The Bank loan would provide $5 million and Shandong Province would contribute an equivalent sum over three years (about Y 16.5 million in 1997, Y 12.5 million in 1998 and Y 12.5 million in 1999). While the size of the Bank contribution has been kept small, the justification for Bank support for the facility derives from, first, the advantages listed above. 19. SEPB would prepare draft operations regulations for XRBSL, setting out the criteria for subloans processing and approvals, the rules and regulations for management, and defining the terms and conditions for loans. Disbursement against this component can begin only after selection of a financial agent to act as the agent in handling loan funds, and the signing of an agreement, acceptable to the Bank, with Shandong Province, setting out the agency agreement. SEPB, with the cooperation of SFB, would deternine the institutional structure and staff composition of the Subloans Management Office (SMO) and approve its annual work plan and budget. 20. The SMO would have up to 12 staff, to be recruited during a three-year period, including specialists in environmental science and technology, industrial processing, economics and finance, and administration. The director would be appointed by SPG, and other staff would be locally recruited. The main role of SMO would be in investment project planning, coordination between borrower and financial agent, review of project feasibility, approval of subloans and supervision of project implementation. The financial appraisal would be the responsibility of the financial agent. The technical appraisal would be contracted to design institutes by the financial agent. 21. Project Selection. Each application would be first reviewed by the local industrial bureau and planning commission to ensure consistency with municipal environmental planning. If the proposed investment appears feasible, the application would be forwarded to SMO for further processing. SMO would lead an environmental appraisal assessing the suitability of the pollution abatement measures proposed to the
 -140- ANNEX 12 effluents produced in the enterprise. The financial agent would carry out a financial appraisal, looking particularly at the appropriateness of the investment given the input and output markets, the quality of enterprise management as demonstrated in their current operating environment and a financial analysis to ensure the enterprise's ability to repay the loan. The technical analysis would be carried out in accordance with the criteria developed in a special training program, and review the designs for easily maintained and operated systems well within the technical competence of enterprise personnel. Project Management Procedures 22. XRBSL operating procedures would include the following: (a) SMO would issue directives and solicitations for project proposals to the priority-area EPBs and planning commissions; (b) With consent from the local industrial bureau, the enterprise would submit a loan application to its EPB and planning commission; (c) If the project appears feasible, the local EPB would forward the loan application to SMO for review and further processing. SMO would carry out an environmental appraisal while the financial agent would make a quick financial assessment of the enterprise; (d) With SMO concurrence, the enterprise would prepare a feasibility report including engineering design, cost estimates, a waste minimization plan prepared by a design institute with expertise in waste minimization, a financial proposal with a time-bound investment plan, and an environmental impact assessment; (e) Upon receiving the feasibility study, the financial agent would undertake a detailed financial appraisal, and contract with a design institute to undertake a technical appraisal; (f) After completion of the financial and technical appraisal, the financial agent would prepare a comprehensive report, including the technical appraisal carried out by the design institute, which, together with the feasibility report, it would send to SMO with its observations and recommendations; (g) After the project has been successfully appraised and approved by SMO, the appraisal report and proposed loan conditions would be submitted by SMO to the World Bank for no-objection. The Bank would provide ex-ante review of the first three subloan projects and thereafter for each subloan of over $300,000, with all other subloans subject to ex-post review;
 -141- ANNEX 12 (h) SEPB, in conjunction with SFB, would be responsible for the final approval of subloan projects. After approval, SMO would confirm the loan to the enterprise, any cofinancing agencies and the financial agent; (i) SMO would take into account the forecast of the original waste minimization audit when assessing the project implementation and focus in particular on the no- and low-cost options implementation; (j) After satisfying itself as to the quality of a commissioned project, the relevant bureau would issue a Certificate of Examination and Acceptance to the enterprise; (k) The bureau in charge would submit examination and acceptance documents for the project to SMO; and (1) SMO would separately assess whether the project meets the design document requirements. If it does not, SMO would arrange for appropriate departments to intervene, seeking necessary amendments to the project. Project Appraisal 23. For the technical appraisal of individual projects, the general criteria to be considered would be: (a) the project's impact on the ambient environment; (b) a waste minimization audit and compliance with environmental regulations and standards (EA), involuntary resettlement (including preparation of a RAP; and (c) technical feasibility and identification of the least-cost option. Design institutes responsible for technical appraisals would have undergone special training in waste minimization. This training has been established with the assistance of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the China National Cleaner Production Center. 24. The financial appraisal must demonstrate that the enterprise, as a whole, would be financially viable, including meeting a debt service ratio larger than 1.4 after the proposed project reaches full production capacity. For joint waste treatment facilities, a financing plan for the operation and maintenance of the facility would be required. Project Financing Procedures Between Financial Agent and Borrower 25. Once a subloan application is approved by SEPB/SFB, the financial agent would execute the loan according to procedures described below: (a) The agent would confirm the project financing plan with the borrower, in accordance with the loan agreement signed between Shandong Province and the enterprise; (b) The enterprise would open an account with the agent;
 -142- ANNEX 12 (c) The agent would disburse funds upon receipt of statement of expenditure, in the form of invoice or letter of credit. Normally, disbursement would be made once a month; (d) The agent would supervise funds use by the enterprise. If project funds are found to have been used for any purpose other than the approved project, the agent would refuse further disbursement and notify SMO; (e) The agent would report to SMO quarterly on the financial status of loans made to borrowers. The agent would also report emerging issues and make suggestions for improvement as needed; (f) At project completion, the agent would finalize the financial accounting; (g) If projects fail to meet project date or design criteria, the agent shall notify SMO; and (h) The agent would undertake the collection of loan principal, interest, late payment penalties and fines. Disbursement would be made through the agent from the account for XRBSL in SFB. Control and Annual Audit of XRBSL 26. The quality of waste minimization audit reports would be checked during the first year of operation by the National Cleaner Production Center (NCPC), located in Beijing. After this first year, an inspection panel involving NCPC, the World Bank and UNEP would evaluate the audit quality and procedure. 27. XRBSL would be audited each financial year by a qualified and independent auditor acceptable to the Bank. The auditor is required to furnish a written report indicating the extent to which the financial statements and supporting information provide a true and fair view of the financial condition and performance of XRBSL. The auditor should also provide a separate management letter following the completion of the audit on any improvements required in the financial systems and controls and improved use of resources. The audit reports and annual accounts should be forwarded to the World Bank within six months of the end of the fiscal year. Loans 28. The aggregate amount of subloans made to any one enterprise shall not exceed the equivalent of $500,000. The aggregate amount of all subloans from XRBSL made for any one subproject shall not exceed the lesser of 50 percent of total estimated project cost (excluding land), or 100 percent of the foreign currency cost. The total estimated cost of each subproject shall not exceed $1 million. Loan maturity would be three to five years, with up to two years of grace. SFB would bear the subloan credit risk, and the enterprise
 -143 - ANNEX 12 the foreign exchange risk. The subloan interest rate would be no less than the standard interest rate for LIBOR-based US dollar single currency loans plus a spread of 1.5 percent per year and a commitment charge of 0.75 percent. Repayments to XRBSL would be recycled for additional subprojects to the extent funds are not needed for repayment of the Bank loan. Institutional Development and Equipment Needs 29. SMO personnel would undergo an extensive training program. Training courses would include waste management, waste reduction technology, particularly resource recovery/recycling and clean technology. Training and equipment for XRBSL would be partly financed under the Management and Agency Strengthening component of the Shandong Environment Project.

The financial projections from 1997 to 2003 for Jinan Municipal Drainage Company (JMDC),were produced by its financial staff in conjunction with company management and planning staff. Inflation and Exchange Rates: Yearly general domestic inflation rates used in the projections are 6.2 percent in 1997, 5.8 percent in 1998, and 5.5 percent thereafter. Price contingency allowances on the foreign costs of Bank-financed projects are expected to average 2.3 percent a year from 1997 to 2003. It is assumed that exchange rate adjustments would, on average, maintain purchasing power parity during the projection period. The initial exchange rate is Y 8.3/$1.O. 3. Financial Covenants: Total revenues should (a) cover operating expenses plus the greater of depreciation or debt service and (b) debt service coverage should be at least 1.3. Income Statement Assumptions 4. Wastewater Sales Revenue: Based on average tariff rates and wastewater sales volumes. The average tariff growth rate is set so that sales revenue would meet operating ratio and debt service coverage covenants. In JMDC, projections of wastewater sales volumes are assumed to be 80 percent of projected water sales volume. In addition, the Water Conservation Office collects revenues from industry based on annual groundwater extraction quotas (80 percent of 91.25 million mi3) multiplied by the average wastewater tariff and passes this revenue on to the drainage company. Average 1997 wastewater 3~~~~~~~~~~3 tariff is Y 0.33/m3. 5. Average Tariffs. Personnel: Operation and maintenance personnel are expected to increase to and then level off at 12 staff/1,000 connections. Wages are expected to increase at the rate of general domestic inflation plus 2 percent ann'ually. 8. Electricity: Expenses are projected to grow in real terms, averaging 8.0 percent per year. This is JMDC's largest expense. Electricity primarily is used to run pumping stations and aerators, before the wastewater treatment plant becomes operational.
